Use Merriam Webster online Dictionary and Thesaurus, which has an audio providing the pronunciation also. Or any other. Listening well and reading intently are the first steps in good oral and written communication. Build your knowledge of grammar (Wren & Martin), syntax, vocabulary and so on. Before you use a particular word, say beautiful, check the online thesaurus for synonyms and use the most appropriate word. Vocabulary is built brick by brick. So learning one new word leads to learning many others. Check the exact meaning of every new word from the dictionary, instead of trying to guess the meaning from its context. Read a lot of good authors. Listen to a lot of good speakers. Yet, in either case, develop your own unique style. Write short speeches, memorize them, internalise them and deliver them before the mirror or a better speaker than you. Practice makes perfect. Join a local Toastmasters Club or other public speaking club. Standing Ovation - Fifteen speeches to steer the budding orator by Sterling Publishers on Amazon will be a great help.

In the immortal words of Suzuki Roshi and Nike sneakers, “just do it.” Take a text and sit with your dictionary and ReversoContext app ready, for any unfamiliar words or expressions. Importantly, choose texts that are at a good level for you and that interest you. Also, parallel texts that have English and your language on facing pages are great for this. You can also read Wikipedia articles in your first language and then in English - however, often these are not direct translations, but rather newly written articles. I like to use Kindle E-books, because you can touch a word and it is automatically defined. However, you will need ReversoContext or Google Translate for phrases. Good Luck!
response.upvotes: Answer requested by William Ferreira and Floyd Master

response.answer_text: Immersion.  Start using English in everything you do.  That's how I did and still doing.  I used to carry a dictionary and a thesaurus and memorize 10 new words a day until I finish A to Z.  Learn to dissect the words of its prefix, suffix, origin will help to simplify the memorization process.  Haste makes waste, take it slow and do not care about embarrassment when learning.  People will help when they see you are trying.  Think of all jeers and criticism as they  are laughing with you NOT at you.  If you think 10 words a day is too much, cut it down to 1.  One new word a day is still good.  But if you can do ten, that's 3,650 new words a year.  Not bad for a starter.  Rome was not built in one day.  So start building and have fun eating an elephant sandwich one bite at a time.

Read aloud. Record yourself. And play back the recording. You'll be surprised at what you sound like. If you want to improve your speed, you'll have to stop mouthing the words. It's a weird habit forced into children by parents and teachers who want to HEAR the kids reading out loud so that they know the children aren't doing anything else. ZIP your mouth shut and read aloud in your mind. Do not move your head from side to side, move your eyes from one line to another. You'll be surprised at how many minutes you'll shave off simply by practicing these 2 things.. and in a competitive exam, every minute counts. Happy fast reading

There are so many ways. One of the most effective and long term is British council courses. Apart from reading and watching English language films you can join a British Council online course- myEnglish. This course focuses on all the four areas listening, speaking, reading and writing. It also focuses on vocabulary a lot. They will assess you and then you will have a phone interview. Post that they will suggest you as per your Caliber on which course to take. Just visit the British council website and opt for my English course. This course has live teacher and students as it is very interesting and interactive. You will definitely enjoy and gain a lot of knowledge as the teachers are CELTA or DELTA certified. You can also go for some classroom sessions near you and converse daily with your tutor and keep asking questions. Remember that only practice will make you succeed in the IELTS.

Depending on what specifically you are having trouble with (pronunciation, speed, comprehension etc.), you definitely want to practice reading everything, all the time. Signs, advertisements, books, subtitles, lyrics, ingredients and more are excellent things to read throughout your day, and by doing this you will become more comfortable with quick site reading and comprehension (these things are pretty easy to understand since they are in the moment). Also with books, you can start with easy stuff like kids’ tales and picture books. Stay consistent and work your way up to more challenging material. Also try sites like these that are fun to play along with and train your brain and pronunciation with audio and visual. The most important thing is that you read A LOT and you are constantly trying to read new things while progressing with traditional literature as well. When all else fails, get a popular story (like Shakespeare etc.) in two languages side by side.

Read light stuff.  Avoid Pope, Dryden, and Shakespeare.  Beowulf will kill your reading speed.  A diet of dense reading will draw your reading speed down to where you can cover material more effectively if you read aloud. So read some Elmore Leonard and such -- writers who use language well, but who write in the first person and use lots of dialogue.  Work at increasing the speed of your reading without losing enjoyment. Then for work, just plough through the stuff looking for key words, without any semblance of enjoyment.  Use a hi-lighter to identify things you need to retain.

Realize that most letters in English (but not all) make a sound, and hear more English. This show helped my kid learn to read: Where Words Come Alive. She reads words that she doesn't know.  When she asks me what word she has read and I tell her, she realizes that she's heard that word before without knowing what it means.  So I say watch shows and listen to podcasts (available for free in iTunes) in English, and look for the words you've heard in what you're reading.  Listening to an audiobook while following along in the actual book would help.

There aren't any abbreviations or tricks to learn English in a few days. Of course ‘a few days’ It self is a relative term. Make a beginning and assess the speed of progress. You can devote more time. It is a hard work and will need persistent efforts. If you are willing to take this path please read on. Be proud of your vernacular background. Your emotional quotient resides your vernacular language. Try and build proficiency in vernacular language. This sound weird???~ Profiency of vernacular language forces you to look for appropriate words in the new language you learn. Besides in the initial stages everyone forms a sentence in the vernacular language he is comfortable with and translates it to ENGLISH. Capabilities of Imagination / structuring a narration / relevance of tenses and such other concepts get transposed from the 1st language to the new language you learn. In this case it is English. Learning any language has following components. 1 - Grammar 2 - Vocabulary 3 - Comprehension ability 4 - Narration / Composition Grammar - Syntax + Tenses Vocabulary - Meaning + Usage Comprehension - Ability to understand written / spoken Narration / Composition - Ability to Express thoughts / Opinions + Structure the narration written or spoken Take a hard look and find out which of above needs to be strengthened. Read novels / Short Stories /Essays. I can suggest a few books. Many of the titles mentioned below have been re- written in simple language. Choose the level you are comfortable with Tomswayer - Mark Twain Jungle Book -Rudyard Kipling My India - Jim Corbet Malgudi Days - R. K. Narayan Wings Of Fire - A.P.J. Abdul Kalam Robinson Crusoe Gulliver's Travels Twenty Thousand Leagues Under The Sea -Jules Verne Around The World In 80 Days Pride and Prejudice - Jane Austin Tale of Two Cities - Charles Dickens Sherlock Holmes Ashenden -Bernard Shaw Oxford's Reading Circle Series Check books by following authors Jonathan Swift Ravindranath Tagore Sudha Murty Arundhati Roy Chetan Bhagat Earnest Hemingway Edgar Allen Poe Keep out academic / science / technology books. They have very small literary footprint and do not help in linguistic sphere. Take a note of the sentences that appeal to you or you find interesting. Similarly note the new words along with their usage. Usage modifies the meaning of the words. Example This book is a shade better than other books. The lawyers arguments exposed shades of hypocrisy. “Wait for me in the tree shade, after you come out of the tuition class”, said my mother. The lamp shade fell of due to turbulent wind. Word game - How many words can you find with 'eat' letter combination. Heat / neat / seat / beat / peat / treat / meat / sweat / cheat / death / threat / create/ wheat great / ….?. Try your luck with different letter combination. 'ust' Dust / Just / Trust /Burst / Must / Lust / Crust / Gusts / Custard /Bust ….??? Coin more challenges like only verbs and see how many you can find. Words with similar themes Danger / risk / endanger / perilous / Pernicious / Precarious Try and use the words in meaningful sentences. Choose a simple topic of your interest or a simple story. Write three to four paragraphs. Read them and see if you can improve the narration. Search for more appropriate words. As you practice choose a bit difficult topic and continue. Stand before the mirror and narrate / speak about some topic without referring to written text. If you can get an audience then get it. Watch documentaries with sub titles. Watch TV News Channels /Discussions As far as technical writing is concerned you need to be precise. You must be well versed with scientific terminology. Example - speed / velocity + Heat /Temperature / Calories you most know the scientific definitions. It is a hard work but the results will surprise you.

My answer as an English learner would be, simply, read.The best way to get good at something is doing it. Of course, what you should read depends heavily on what you're exercising for, and what's your starting point. Do you need it for work?Are doing it just for your own pleasure?How much time can you take for this activity? One general advice that applies to all cases is reading magazines and/or newspapers: you'll generally find a good mix of formal and informal expressions, plus you'll get a good grip of the culture and the general common sense of that population. Hope this helps, will add more as it comes to mind!

Try these: Read slower. Read out loud. After a few sentences or a paragraph, ask youself what the selection meant. Read to a friend. Talk about the selection. Use a highlighter; highlight words or phrases that seem to indicate a main idea. Take notes about what you have read. If you attend a public school or a community college, go to a counselor. There are reading specialists and there is support for disabilities (dyslexia, ADD).

Practice, practice, practice. Read (a lot). Find what you like to read, and read that. If you like young adult fantasy, by all means read that. If you like dense biographies of famous people, go ahead and read that. Don't let anyone's opinion of the material ("that's trash" "why would you read that?" "no, you have to read these classics instead") turn you from reading what you like to reading something that will turn you off reading. And keep at it. The best way to improve your language skills is through exposure. So don't ask, what is the best thing for me to read to improve my  English? Just ask yourself what you enjoy, and go with that. You're not out to impress anyone with your list of reading material, you're out to improve your skills. Which can be done just as effectively with any genre.

Learn the sounds of the letters if you don't know them already. Then learn the other sounds made when letters are joined together, such as ie, ar, er, ir, or, ur, etc. This will help you pronounce the words correctly and improve your speech. I suggest reading plays, nothing older than 1900, because they have the most conversation. You will learn how people talk. Twelve Angry Men and The Night of January 16th are good ones. Don't read newspapers, especially the Wall Street Journal, because they use too many puns, euphemisms, and idioms.

If you have trouble with the Egnlish grammar, you can find a book that specific on English grammar, remember those things. Having a good basic is the better/fast way to learn something. Try to learn the grammar which governs English as it is a little tricky but not too hard to master if you put your mind to it. 3. Take a course: The beautiful thing about the internet is that if it is used for the right purposes, it can make your life so much more simpler! There are loads of on-line courses available for understanding as well as writing English. Ex:http://alison.com/learn/English My fourth option would be Quora but it seems you have beat me to it!  Hopefully this helps.  Cheers!

Read, read, read. Just go to your local library, take out whatever books look interesting to you, and read them. This is one of those skills where the only way to get better is by practice, so devouring as many books as you can get your hands on is the best way to approach it. I would also recommend that you read books of all different styles, some gothic literature, some sci fi, some non fiction, so that you can have a more wide understanding of literature. I wish you the best of luck with your reading journey!

Reading Comprehension in English can be improved by the following ways:- 1.Read Newspapers: Try to read one article, one paragraph and after reading it try to make a small summary in your notebook. Try this for atleast a week. It will help you to comprehend/understand the paragraph better. 2. Books: If you want to improve your reading comprehension for some comepetive exam than you can try book by Arun Sharma and Meenakshi Upadhyay. The book name is ‘How to prepare for Verbal Ability and Reading Comprehension For The Cat' by MC Graw Publications.

Read a wide variety of styles and subject matter. Variety is the spice of life, as the old saying goes. It’s also the spice of understandability. Reading different kinds of writing styles and subject matter helps to extend your ‘range’ — your knowledge and familiarity of the different ‘textures’ of operation of the English language. So read beyond your textbooks and set materials. There are no shortcuts to this. Thanks for the A2A.

You should look into something called "extensive reading." It basically means reading as much as possible. Try to find materials that don't feel very difficult, and that you will enjoy (whatever type of materials you most enjoy reading in your native language). The idea is that you read something that you enjoy, it's easy to stay motivated, and it becomes progressively easier and more enjoyable, which leads you to be able to read more and to gradually move on to more difficult material.

Reading anything helps, of course! Is there something you have to read? Start with that. Or, are you preparing for a specific situation (reading emails)? That should help you. Some other ideas are reading Wikipedia. There is a “Simple English” language option you can use until you feel more confident. (Reading more is better than reading very little, but at a higher level). If you can’t think of anything else, I have a series of stories for English learners that I made for my students. They include vocabulary explanations and review. They could help, too.

But, you wrote your question nicely, in english. You did good! Anyway, I am going to suggest you to practice, practice, and practice. Try to write, listen to, and speak in English. Everyday. You may find your way in how you do it. I also suggest that you look up on his profile, he has answered many questions about learning English greatly. Mikhail Kotykhov.  Well, have the courage to try to communicate in English! Good luck! Since, I am not a native speaker, and still learning English, there could be mistakes in my writing. I welcome edits.

Tell a librarian you want to improve your reading skills. Tell her what kind of books you like. Ask her to suggest some books.    Start reading. Have a dictionary at your side. I am trying to learn Spanish and I have a Spanish-English dictionary in book form. I also have an electronic one. There are online dictionaries that translate. Try to guess unknown words' meanings from the context. If you can't do that look them up. Make a written note of them with their definitions.    Also I suggest you get poems, short stories and essays to read. They are not as long as books and so might give you a quicker feeling of accomplishment.

It will come with practice.Start with reading small passages.As and when you find new words underline them and look up their meaning in a dictionary.Over time increase the size of the passages that you will read and need to comprehend.Start solving comprehensions that come with questions.That way you will be able to understand better as well.You will get there eventually :)

Start to read “stuff” you are interested in. The more the interest, the more carefully you will read. The best things there are topics that can improve your life (life, health, practical skills, etc ) as there you have a real investment in understanding what you are reading, Hard to read well, when you have little or no interest in what you read. Or when it has no impact on your life.

It's useful to find reading material that's just a little outside your comfort level. Then, when you encounter a passage that contains words or phrases you don't understand, you can probably guess the meaning from the context. Gradually, you should be able to read more and more complex material.

First,select simple but interesting topics to read.Test your comprehension by answering questions. Next,move on to reading articles of a higher level, Try to follow assumed reading,where you guess the meaning of difficult words in the context.If words are of higher level of difficulty, consult a dictionary.Get tests administered,to check improvement.Make reading, a regular habit.

Step One: Find your true level in English. Find out which books you can read easily. If it’s hard going, it isn’t working. Find something easier. Step Two: Read. Read for content and for your own pleasure. Read for the enjoyment of reading. Read until you forget you’re reading in English.

If you are headed for a career in a particular industry read papers published in that field. Otherwise if you wish to speak, understand, read and write at a reasonably sophisticated level read the New York Times, which will have a large variety of stories from pop culture to almost academic study-level writing (almost but not quite) in long feature pieces.

a) Read any books written in English, of course b) Let other people (say, your teacher) make problem sets based on what you read before c) Try to solve them without reading back the book d) Repeat, repeat, repeat e) Consult any of English dictionaries if you don’t understand some words (but don’t use WordNet!)

There are already a lot of great answers here for improving your English reading skills. However, I noticed in your question details that you mention your Cambridge score. Are you looking to improve a test score? If you're doing one of the Cambridge Exams, it's very important to read a large variety of subjects. The test articles sound similar to what you would read in things such as the National Geographic, travel and general public science magazines as well as general interest reading sources. If you can get a good grasp of these articles, understanding sub-context and implied information, you'll go a long way in improving your test score.

About your writing, there is no way to improve it than writing English everyday. Go on Twitter or Tumblr, make an account and then write about your life in English.
